texts.es: Ericka de la Concepción tiene 36 años de edad es una joven emprendedora que se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general, ella ya tiene sus clientes fijos y eventuales en el cual la visitan. Ericka tiene 2 niño que todavía están a su cargo y lucha por darle lo mejor y sacarlo adelante. Ericka está solicitando que le brindo financiamiento para poder comprar mercadería y ofrecerles a sus cliente variedad  de producto, ella comprara ropa, zapatos, cosméticos otro productos que más le demanda a sus clientes.
texts.en: Ericka de la Concepcion is 36 years old. She is a young entrepreneur who sells general merchandise. She has steady and one-off customers who visit her. Ericka is the mother of two children who still depend on her. She works to provide them with the best and help them to progress. Ericka is requesting a loan to buy merchandise and offer her clients a variety of products. She will buy clothes, shoes, cosmetics and other products that are on high demand by her clients.

loans.use: to buy clothes, shoes, cosmetics and other products.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with three children, and all of them go to school. She also cares for her father. Her house has electricity and piped water, and her major monthly expenses include food and work-related expenses.

For the last five years Rose has sold Cavendish bananas at the market, seven days a week. She must pay dues to sell there. Thieves and the seasonality of bananas are her major challenges.

Rose has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy more bunches of Cavendish bananas. Her aspiration is to become a wholesaler.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of Cavendish bananas to sell.

loans.name: Victor Manuel

texts.es:
Victor con 54 años de edad,de estado civil conviviente, vive en casa familiar,junto a su cónyuge y su hijo, en el distrito de Cayaltí,provincia de Chiclayo,departamento de Lambayeque,país Perú. El cuenta con muy buenas referencias tanto personales como laborales por parte de los moradores de la zona. Los habitantes de esta localidad se dedican en su mayoría a la agricultura,comercio y ganadería.

El se dedica a la fabricación de ventanas,puertas,pasamanos,etc, de aluminio,con una experiencia en el rubro desde hace más de 5 años. Solicita préstamo para la compra de material para poder fabricar más puertas,ventanas,etc. De esta manera le facilitará seguir trabajando.

Victor es socio reactivado para Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: ara la compra de material para poder fabricar más puertas,ventanas,etc.

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.en:
This is a group loan request submitted by the five members of the Nanoor association, represented by Mamadou F..  The Nanoor group hails from the coastal fishing village of Palmerin, where the surrounding grasslands are ideal for livestock grazing.  Mamadou and his associates plan to take advantage of this natural resource by purchasing a quantity of young goats to raise.  Goat meat is always in demand in Palmarin and the surrounding areas, where it is commonly stewed in a spicy sauce and served over millet.  The Nanoor group considers their enterprise a sound investment, as a young goat purchased for about $30 will easily fetch $50 after four months of fattening on Palmerin’s good pastureland.  They have committed to begin repaying their loan in monthly instalments four months after receipt of funding, giving them enough time to purchase, raise, fatten and begin to sell the goats.

 

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group.  Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, which provide the rural poor throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities.  Repayment rates within these groups are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members.  However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income.  This has prevented the traditional associations from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities.  Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works with our partner organization CRESP to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Purchase of young goats

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Margaret would like to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Soraida

texts.en:
Soraida lives in a rural community outside Consuelo with her husband and their five children. She runs her own small grocery store, known in the Dominican Republic as a colmadito. She used her first loan from Esperanza to start the business, which is now ready to expand.

Now that she has successfully paid off her first loan, Soraida is elligible for a second, larger loan that will help her to take the next step out of poverty. With five growing children to feed, clothe and put through school, Soraida is in need of expanding her business to increase profits so she can provide adequately for her family and save for their future.

Her plan is to invest in fresh produce and dairy products to round out the products that she offers, which currently are prepackaged household items, canned food and beverages. Soraida is determined to work hard and has recruited her husband to expand their family business to its full potential. With this loan of $300, she will have the funds to move forward in her business plan.

loans.use: Expand inventory to include fresh produce and dairy products

loans.name: Mballu

texts.en: Mballu C. is thirty-three years old.  She is married with five children.  In her small store in Makeni town of Sierra Leone, she sells both wholesale and retail.  As with many women in Sierra Leone, Mballu’s husband's earnings as a teacher are too small to support the family’s upkeep.  Her income from the business supplements her husband’s income.  She intends to use the loan to purchase forty gallons of palm oil to increase her stock for better profit.

loans.use: Forty gallons of palm oil

loans.name: Ramona

texts.en:
Ramona is 40 years old and is a single mother to a 22-year old son. A few years ago, Ramona had to travel to Argentina, a country bordering Paraguay, in search of better job opportunities. There, she worked as a maid and, after saving a little money, returned to her country to open her own business.

She opened a small grocery store in a room in her home and, because it is in a good location and there is little competition, she has many customers. She wants to continue to make progress and later expand the size of her store.

She is requesting this loan to purchase additional inventory for her shop - fruits, vegetables, flour, oil and rice.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Ramona tiene 40 años de edad, es madre soltera de un hijo de 22 años. Varios años atrás, Ramona tuvo que viajara a la Argentina (país limítrofe con Paraguay) en busca de mayores oportunidades de trabajo. Trabajo como empleada domestica, y luego de ahorrar un poco de dinero volvió a su país para abrir su propio negocio. Monto una despensa en su propia casa, y gracias a su buena ubicación posee una gran cantidad de clientes ya que en la zona hay muy poca competencia. Ella desea ir progresando de a poco y más adelante ampliar el negocio construyendo un salón más grande. El préstamo que solicita será destinado para la compra de más mercaderías para su despensa, tales como frutas, verduras, harina, aceite y arroz.

loans.use: To buy fruits, vegetables, flour, oil and rice.

loans.name: Juan De Mato

texts.es:
Juan is a gentleman who stands out for being one of the best neighbors in his area, and his kindness increased when he decided to install a telephone in his small home to offer its services to the families in his community. He and his family, composed of his wife and five children, are very happy because they have been able to alleviate the lack of communication that existed until now.

Never the less, some irresponsible people who belong to a gang of delinquents stole everything from him a short time ago and hurt his hopes of progressing. When this happened, he planned to leave everything and move, but the strength and support of his wife and children made him understand how important his work was and how necessary this service was for so many people.

This is why he decided to confront his adversaries one more time. He understands that it's better to protect his home even more to provide security for the people that visit him and his family with the objective of maintaining communication between this small town and the rest of the world.

Let's make it possible for this hard-working father to keep his and many other families united through his every day work.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer.

Juan es un caballero que se caracteriza por ser uno de los mejores vecinos de la localidad y su simpatía se incrementó cuando decidió instalar en su pequeña morada un teléfono para ofrecer sus servicios a las familias de su comunidad. Él y su familia conformada por su esposa y cinco hijos están muy contentos porque han podido aliviar la falta de comunicación que existía hastya ahora.

Sin embargo las personas inconscientes que conformaron una banda de delincuentes le arrebataron todo hace poco tiempo y lastimaron sus deseos de progresar, cuando ocurrió este hecho pensó dejar todo y marcharse sin embargo la fortaleza y apoyo de su esposa e hijos le hicieron comprender lo importante de su labor y lo necesario que era este servicio para muchas personas.

Así que decidió hacerle frente a las adversidades una vez más y ha comprendido que lo mejor es proteger aún más su espacio para brindarle seguridad a las personas que lo visitan y a su amorosa familia con el objetivo de seguir manteniendo la comunicación desde este pequeño espacio hasta el resto del mundo.

Hagamos posible que este trabajador padre de familia mantenga unida a su familia y a muchas otras a través de su desempeño diario.

loans.use: To implement security sensors for the small call center

loans.name: Paula Matilde

texts.en:
Paula and her husband certainly have their hands full with six children, ranging from fourteen years to two months old.  Paula’s husband works as a gardener in areas around their community, while she balances the responsibility of Mom and entrepreneur at home.

Paula has started a small shop in her home, where she sells fashion accessories and undergarments.  Her products incluD. semi-precious jewels, hair ties, barrettes, decorative scarves, and other things as well.  Her inventory is small, and she plans on using her loan to maintain an assorted collection of these trinkets and fashionable accessories.  Paula hopes that her business will grow as quickly as her children, particularly her four boys, and that she will be able to generate income for her family while spending time at home.

loans.use: To Purchase Jewelry and Fashion Accessories

loans.name: Jesca's Group

texts.en:
Jesca N. is a 32 year old married mother of 4, ages 11, 9, 6, and 3, who sells used clothing. She wants the loan to increase her stock and plans to invest the additional profits to start a piggery business.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To increase her stock of clothing

loans.name: Hajra's Group

texts.en:
My name is Hajra A. and I live with my family in the small town of Pakpattan, Pakistan. My family consists of my husband and five children, three daughters and two sons. My husband supports us by selling chickens in the food market while I sell milk from my house. We are applying for this loan to expand my husband's business.

The members of my group who require loans are: Amina B. and Zahida P., each of whom will use the loan to buy an additional cow. Sadiqa B. will use the loan to expand her cradle-making business.

loans.use: To expand several small businesses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing of office supplies for selling.

loans.name: Bemilda Esperanza

texts.es:
Benilda is 59 years old and lives in Waspan North, with her husband who is now retired and the money he receives they use to pay for the house expenses, her 4 children are older and independents, they support them monthly with a little money. She has had a small neighborhood store for 40 years which she started with her savings and now it is a fountain of support for her and her husband. She requests a loan to purchase various products such as groceries, basic grains, and other things to benefit the store, at her age this work represents for her a success and it has helped to pay the expenses of the house.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Benilda de 59 años de edad habita en Waspan Norte, con su esposo quien ya esta jubilado y el dinero que recibe se lo entrega para que lo administre en el gasto de la casa, sus 4 hijos todos mayores e independientes le apoyan mensualmente con un poco de dinero. Tiene 40 años de tener una pulpería la cual inició con sus ahorros y ahora es la fuente de sustento de ella y su viejito a como de cariño le dice a su esposo. Solicita un crédito para comprar productos varios de alimentos, granos básicos y surtir mejor su pulpería, a su edad este trabajo representa para ella un logro ya que cuando lo inició era ama de casa y fue de su iniciativa que ahora tiene este pequeño negocio que mantiene sus gastos y los de su casa.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products

loans.name: Raquel

texts.es:
Raquel is married, just like her three children. She began this business in order to help her husband with family expenses. She got this business going three years ago, selling merchanside to family and friends.

She requests a credit of $250 which she will pay back in three months. She will use the money to purchase a bag of clothes because her sales are increasing.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

Raquel es casada y sus hijos ya están casados. Inicio su negocio para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos familiares, inicio hace 3 años comprando una paca de ropa y vendiendo entre sus vecinos y amistades en mercados rodantes.

Solicita un crédito por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar una paca de ropa ya que sus ventas se están incrementando. Con tu ayuda seguirá adelante.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is an entrepreneur from the southern Ukrainian city of Melitopol. She sells a variety of small clothing items including socks, hosiery and hats at an outdoor market in Melitopol. Tatyana has a good place to sell in the market with lots of passing traffic and a visible location. She has had her own business for the past twelve years. Divorced, her business is a very important source of income. She has two children – a son who is married and has a family and a daughter who was just recently married. Tatyana is able to help both of her children with the income she makes.

Tatyana has requested a loan of 5000 Ukrainian Griven to increase her working capital. This will allow her to purchase new inventory and continue developing her business.

loans.use: Increase working business capital

loans.name: Victor Ignacio

texts.es:
Victor is married, lives in the Oswaldo Manzanarez neighborhood and is 43 years old. He has three children who are 2, 20 and 25 years of age. His wife helps him with their business. Victor rents out rooms and also has a sorbet shop. He started these businesses 10 years ago with his own funds. The loan that he is requesting is to improve his sorbet shop so that he may provide better service to his customers. In the future, he plans to grow his shop since it is located on a strategic route allowing him to increase capital and earn better income.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Don Víctor es casado, habita en el barrio Oswaldo Manzanarez, y tiene 43 años de edad, le tienen tres hijos de 2, 20 y 25 años de edad, su esposa ayuda en el negocio que tienen. El negocio del Sr. Víctor es el alquiler de cuartos y tiene una sorbeteria, lleva diez años de experiencia el inició con fondos propios. Con el préstamo que está solicitando es para mejoras de local en el negocio de la sorbeteráa para dar mejor servicio con el ambiente a sus clientes. A futuro es seguir ampliando el local de la sorbeteria ya que esta en una ruta estratégica para seguir aumentando el capital y así tener mejores ganancias.

loans.use: Invest in infrastructure of his sorbet shop.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Mrs. Kim Y., 29, is a farmer. She grows rice on her farmland and earns around $3 per day. Her husband, Mr. Lach Pheak, 29, is a bricklayer and earns around $4 per day. He has been working since 1998. They have three young children, all of whom are in school and living in Spean Village, Pursat Province. Mrs. Kim Y. needs a loan of $500 to purchase fertilizer for the rice and to purchase a pig to raise.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL):

HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her rice crop and to purchase a pig to raise

loans.name: Fuente De La Esperanza Group

texts.en:
Santiago Atitlan has been a major city since early Mayan times and is situated on the hillside of beautiful Lake Atitlan. Atitlan is known around the lake for the strong presence of the Mayan Tzutujil people. 

Despite this interesting background and beautiful scenery, the women from the group tell me this town can be dangerous at times. This is especially true for women, who are already greatly under pressure to keep their families running, and sometimes deal with attacks and suffer from the hard laws of the street. The troubled times caused by the Civil War during the eighties have influenced Santiago's contemporary reality very much; this is why Conception, who does most of the talking for the group, thinks that life in Santiago is, even today, a difficult one.
 
Pride and the continuing search for a better life keeps the women of this group going and they are working hard to improve their lives and the lives of the ones they love.

Most of the women work in embroidery. The Santiago Atitlan embroidery is delightful. Artisans will weave beautiful birds and Mayan symbols in their typical blouses called Guipiles.  For almost all of the women this is their second, third or fourth loan. There are even some women who came from another group and have managed to establish their lives quite well after 8 years of microfinance loans, says Josefa, who is one of them herself. Josefa is the president of the group. While working in her convenience shop that she has managed to build, she works on embroidery too. She is also very happy to be able to help the younger members of the group to learn how to invest their credit well. 

Conception says that it is everybody's wish to take advantage of every opportunity they have to talk to foreigners. This is because talking to foreigners is an opportunity for them to show their beautiful art to the world and this can become an opportunity to sell or even export their goods to other countries. Selling their products to foreigners will generate the earnings they deserve, especially during the tough rainy season when the prices of their weavings drop dramatically and the competition increases. This is because there is too much competition in the local market and their weavings are sold at very low prices. This means they sometimes have to sell their products under production costs just to get some money for future investments. The rest of the group very much agreed with her and gave Conception a round of applause because she has expressed herself well.

loans.use: Invest in materials

loans.name: Awaou

texts.fr: Née le 04/02/1958 au Sénégal, dame A. Awaou est divorcée et mère de 3 enfants dont 2 sont à sa charge.Spécialisée dans l’activité de vente de fagots de bois de chauffage depuis 12 ans, elle a sollicité pour son premier prêt à ALIDé un montant de 30000 F CFA pour augmenter son stock de fagots et faire face aux demandes de sa clientèle qui s’accroît de jour en jour. Actuellement elle est à son quatrième crédit et pour lequel elle sollicite 100000 F CFA.
texts.en:
Born on February 4, 1958 in Sénégal, Ms. Awaou A. is divorced and the mother of three children, two of whom are in her care. A specialist in selling bundles of firewood for twelve years, she requested her first loan with Alidé in the amount of 30,000 francs CFA to increase her stock of bundled firewood and to address the demands of her customer base, which grows from day to day. Currently, she is on her fourth loan, for which she is requesting 100,000 francs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bundles of firewood

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es: Daniel tiene 38 años, él y su esposa tienen tres hijos, todos ellos son oriundos de la zona llamada Nagazu.   Durante toda su vida se dedicó al cultivo de sus tierras, siembra café, plátano y también en esta temporada ha sembrado caigua, él creció con las actividades de la chacra, porque su padre fue agricultor, conoce cómo y cuándo tiene que ir cultivando a cada producto.  Le agrada  mucho el cuidado de cada planta, porque cada proceso es diferente, pero siente una gran incomodidad por los precios del guano de isla y demás fertilizantes por que invierte mucho y gana muy poco. Pero sus sueños están en la agricultura, con el tiempo le gustaría tener una casa de material noble y no de maderas, como ahora.  El y su esposa se esfuerzan para adquirir su propia casa, y tener qué heredarles a sus hijos, asimismo darles una buena educación, que ellos no pudieron tener.  Con el dinero abonará su chacra de caigua para la floración y de ese modo agarre fruto, también sembrará mas pacay en su huerto. Si cumple con todo el abonado y el fumigado de la caigua y se desarrolla bien y esto le permitirá cosechar en gran cantidad para el verano y tener un buen precio.
texts.en:
Daniel is 38 years old, he and his wife have three children, all of them born in the Nagazu area. His entire life has been devoted to cultivating his fields. He plants coffee, bananas and also during this season he plants caigua (a vine which grows a small gourd-shaped fruit, used as a vegetable). He grew up with farming activities because his father was a farmer, and he knows how and when to grow each product. He likes taking care of the plants because the process for each is different. He is concerned about the price of guano (manure from sea birds) and other fertilizers because he invests a lot and earns very little. But his dreams are based on farming. In time he would like to have a house made of solid material, not of wood as he now has. He and his wife are trying to buy their own house so they have something to leave as an inheritance to their children as well as giving them a good education, something which neither were able to have. With a loan he will fertilize his caigua fields so they blossom and bear fruit. He will also plant more pacay (a Peruvian leguminous tree, cultivated for its large white edible pods) in his orchard. If he is able to finish fertilizing and fumigating the caigua and everything goes well, he will be able to harvest a large amount this summer and get a good price.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in organic and chemical fertilizers for his crops

loans.name: Mrs. Reaksmey Sar Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan which consists of twelve people is located in Ta Reab Doun S. village in Kandal Province. Mrs. Reaksmey S. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a 43 year old housewife and the mother of four children, all of whom are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Koem Muny, repairs bicycles. In this business, he now faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to buy bike equipment for his customers. Thus, his wife, Mrs. Reaksmey S., decided to ask for a loan to buy more bike equipment for her husband's business.

loans.use: To buy more bike equipment for her husband's business.

loans.name: Nasuuti Women's Group

texts.en: N. Fatumah is 35 years of age and the chairperson of Nasuuti women’s group, a new group in Mukono. She is married with 4 children. One of her children has just finished her Senior 4 leaving examinations; one is in Senior 3, another is in her Primary 7 vacation, and the last-born is in Primary 4. Fatumah cares for her mother and two brothers-in-law. She has a restaurant business called Bismillah Restaurant which she has been running for 2 years, and she is happy that her good services and customer care has enabled her to keep a good clientele. In her business, she is helped by her family members while her husband does other businesses. She prepares breakfast, lunch and supper with very nice meals bringing out the aroma all over the place. This is her first loan with Pearl Microfinance and she has planned to buy and stock food stuffs for her restaurant.

loans.use: To buy and stock food stuffs for her restaurant.

loans.name: Tavai Karen

texts.en: Tavai Karen S., 25, is married with 2 children.  She has 4 years of experience in the vegetable garden business. She sells to the village people and general public 6 days per week.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (~62 USD).  SPBD loans are Tavai Karen’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase cabbage, fertilizer, knives, chemicals

loans.name: Haleema Sheikh Ali Hassan Group

texts.en:
Haleema is 38 years old, married, and lives in Borewala, Pakistan. Her husband, S. A. H., is a driver and operates an auto-rickshaw. Haleema has two daughters, both of whom are attending kindergarten.

Haleema believes in the power of good work. She prepares embroidered dresses and clothes for her neighbors, and is able to earn a steady income from her work. She believes that contributing her own income to the family helps provide her children with the necessary support they need and the education to succeed.

Haleema is currently requesting a loan to help repair and maintain her husband’s auto-rickshaw. She participates in a loan group, which is formed from several women in her local community. Rabia Basri baji wants to purchase groceries and other supplies to restock her own store. Amanat baji wants to expand her current stock of wires and switch boards for her electric item retailing business. Farida baji wants to purchase clothes to expand her own business inventory.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To pay for the installments of auto-rickshaws (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Noel

texts.en:
44-year-old Noel B. is a rice grower. Aside from farming, he also raises ducks and chickens. He earns income from selling rice, ducks, chickens and eggs . He is currently single but hopes to get married soon. He is saving money for his future family. 

For 30 years, he has been tilling his family's farm where his parents taught him to grow rice. Part of his harvest is given to his parents while the rest is sold to his friends and rice traders.

He is asking a loan of Php 10,000. He will use the loan to buy fertilizer and insecticide for his farm. He is also interested in venturing in other lines of business so that he will have more money to save for his future family.

CEVI gives all their clients credit assistance to support their business. They also provide training and insurance coverage to all their clients.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and insecticide

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric N. is 45 years old. He is married and has five children (two males and three females). They are all currently in school at the polytechnic, senior high and junior schools. He says one of the daughters is learning a trade. His wife trades to support him financially.

Eric lives with his family in a rented apartment in a small farming community called Nkwateng in the Eastern Region of Ghana. The major occupation of the residents, the men in particular, is farming.

Eric owns a palm plantation. He does not sell the raw, harvested palm fruits but adds value to it by producing palm oil. He also procures additional palm fruits from nearby farms to increase his production. Eric distributes to customers who come to buy in bulk and retail.

He wants a loan to procure palm fruits in bulk so that he can produce in bulk and distribute to his increasing number of customers. He aspires to complete a building project with the proceeds that will accrue from his business.

loans.use: To procure palm nuts

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria Naa Mensah is widowed with four children. She is a 48-year-old trader. She sells mother care products, such as diapers and Pampers, by hawking (selling door-to-door). When the market for these products falls, she quickly switches to selling food, such as yam and eggs.

She says that her business has been a great help to her in taking care of her children's educational needs as single parent. She buys Pampers and diapers in boxes in Accra. Then she opens the boxes and sells the diapers one at a time.

Gloria has been in this business ten years. She lives with her family in Elmina, a fishing community where most of the people fish in the sea. She identified mother care products to be the very things that most mothers require, because a whole pack of diapers is expensive to buy. She started her business on a small scale, thinking that her market size would be static. She took the advice of an officer about how to treat and retain customers, and she has lived by that advice, which is working for her business. Now, she can boast of an increase in her market size.

However, her problem is that she does not have sufficient working capital to run her business now that her customers base is increasing. With this loan, she wants to inject more working capital into the business. She believes the loan will enable her to purchase good quality stock to upgrade her inventory. She would be grateful for that assistance. She belongs to the village bank called "Try God."

loans.use: Gloria wants a loan to buy more diapers, napkins, eggs, and yams.

loans.name: Abla

texts.fr: D. abla réside dans le quartier de kégué, un quartier de la ville de lomé. Elle est mariée. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale. Son stock est épuisé, elle veut se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter  10 sacs de riz parfumé, 08 bidons d’huile, 04 cartons de savons et de 06 cartons de pâtes alimentaires.
texts.en:
D. Abla resides in Kégué, a district of the city of Lomé. She is married and works to earn an income in the grocery business. Her stock of goods is exhausted. She wants to resupply herself and is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy ten sacks of aromatic rice, eight drums of oil, four boxes of soap, and six boxes of pasta.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grocery items

loans.name: Mansour

texts.fr: MR MANSOUR G. EST NE EN 1980 A DIOURBEL .IL EST CHAUFFEUR DE PROFESSION ET POSSEDE UN VEHICULE PERSONNEL QUI EST SA PRINCIPALE SOURCE DE REVENU .AVEC CE PRET IL VEUT REPARER SON VEHICULE QUI A QUELQUES PANNES.
texts.en:
Mr. Mansour G. was born in 1980 in Diourbel. He is a professional driver and has his own car which is his principal source of revenue. With this loan, he wants to repair his car which has several things wrong with it.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: repairing his vehicle used for public transport

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy new summer clothing for women.

loans.name: Hishigjargal

texts.en: Hishigjargal D. lives with her husband and two children in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her oldest daughter, 8 years old, is a 2nd grade student in a local high school. Her youngest daughter is just 1 year old and stays home. Khishigjargal runs a small public bathhouse for locals. These bath houses are quite common in places like Arhangai province since many of the local people live in traditional tents and do not have any access to hot water. They visit here once in a while and take hot showers for sanitary purposes. Since there are only two bathhouses in the town, many locals often come in her bathhouse and take hot showers. Her husband helps in her business and takes care of heating the bathhouse.  She requests a loan to purchase coal for heating her bathhouse.

loans.use: To buy coal to heat bathhouse.

loans.name: Hamna

texts.en:
Hamna is the daughter of M. D.. She lives in Kabul, Afghanistan and is married with four children.

Hamna is a tailor and she works hard to earn money for the completion of her family’s requirements. She needs to buy a new sewing machine for her business because she has lots of problems with the old one she has. Besides that, she wants to hire a student to support her in her business and to enlarge her business.

Hamna wants to take an individual loan of 14,000 Afghani. She is very glad that she has the chance to progress.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for her business

loans.name: Fenie

texts.en:
Fenie M. is from the village of Unidos. She is 29 years old. Fenie is married and has 1 school aged child. To make a living, Fenie owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Fenie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Fenie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fenie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Fenie is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 13th loan taken out by Fenie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & have available working capital

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen A. is from the village of Baybay Panalsalan. She is 40 years old, is married, and has four adult children.

Helen owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Helen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase piglets to raise and sell.

Helen is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Nazira

texts.en:
B. Nazira started a grocery business 7 years ago. She started off with few products, but her business has grown as she has many frequent clients. Nazira would like a loan of 6400 Somoni to buy merchandise so that she can offer a wider variety of products and so that her business can grow, as clients are always asking her for new things. Nazira and her family thank you very much for your support, which means that her business can grow and she can fulfill her goal of providing for her family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Buy more foodstuffs to increase of the range of goods sold.

loans.name: Tarlay United Group

texts.en:
Tarlay United is a group of 5 borrowers led by Jasa K.. They live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. Jasa  is 31 years old and single with 3 children ages 5-15. All of her children are in school. She also supports 2 children who were orphaned in the war. Jasa was unable to attend school, although she enjoyed it, because the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide and, therefore, school was considered unnecessary. She lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia.

Jasa’s sells clothing, including slippers, shirts, pants, and underwear, which she buys wholesale in nearby Guinea and sells in a temporary market stall on the Kolahu-Foya highway. She has run her business for 4 years and is successful because of her business and finance skills. She’s taking the loan to increase her inventory of clothing which sell well in the rainy season. Her dream is to expand her business so that one day she can have the biggest table in the central market and ultimately her own permanent shop. With the profits from her business, Jasa dreams of building her own house.

loans.use: Purchase slippers, shirts, and pants

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.es:
Aurelia es socia del Banco Comunal Lila.
Aurelia es casada, tiene 37 años y 7 hijos, Aurelia vende leña en su casa, producto que adquiere de los productores, además los días sábados y domingos viaja a las ferias en donde vende ropa.
Aurelia necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de leña y ropa.
Los sueños de Aurelia son que su negocio crezca y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Para la compra de leña y ropa.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth sells bags of cement in retail to her customers in Sapele, Delta state, Nigeria.She hopes for the loan amount of N60,000 to purchase more bags of cement to sell. She is 46 years old and married with 6 children. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of cement to sell

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel D. is from the village of Cabacungan, Claveria Misamis Oriental. She is 27 years old. Maricel is married and has two infant children. To make a living, Maricel owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Maricel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Maricel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jovita

texts.es:
Jovita tiene 40 años, está casada y madre de 4 hijos, de los cuales 2 de ellos viven en su casa.
En compañía de su esposo, se dedica a limpiar su terreno de cultivo, remover la tierra, sembrar, abonar y fumigar durante 7 a 8 meses, sus cultivos de papa y olluco. Luego de que terminar de laborar en el campo se dedican a la crianza de ganado, como carneros y cerdos, los cuales son llevados al mercado para venderlos al precio según su peso y tamaño. De esta manera mueve su capital, mientras esperar la temporada de cosecha.
Pese que la papa es un producto muy riesgoso, a Jovita le gusta este cultivo; por lo que complementa sus ganancias con la venta de animales.
Es así que con estas dos actividades puede balancear sus ingresos si alguna de ellas tiene alguna pérdida; y de ese modo sus hijos no pasan necesidades.

Este es su cuarto crédito con MFP y en todo este tiempo no ha tenido problemas para pagar sus cuotas a tiempo. Además, ella es una mujer muy alegre y siempre entusiasma a los demás miembros de su banco comunal. El dinero que ahora solicita es para comprar más animales, así como fertilizantes químicos para asegurar una buena cosecha.
texts.en:
Jovita is 40 years old. She is married and the mother of 4 children, of which 2 live in her house. Along with her husband, she is dedicated to clearing their croplands, turning the soil, sowing, fertilizing and fumigating for 7 to 8 months their crop of potatoes and olluco (an Andean root vegetable). After finishing their labor in the fields, they work breeding livestock such as sheep and hogs, which are carried to market to sell at a price based on their weight and size. In this manner they generate working capital, while waiting to harvest their crop. Despite the fact that potatoes are a very risky product, Jovita likes this crop, which is why she supplements her profits with the sale of animals. With these two activities she can balance her income if she has a loss with one or the other; and that way her children do not suffer hardship. This is her fourth loan with MFP and in all this time she has not had problems to make her payments on time. Besides, she is a very happy woman and always encourages the others member of her communal bank. The money that she now requests is to buy more animals, as well as chemical fertilizers to assure a good crop.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her potato crop and more animals.

loans.name: Suma Pacha Group

texts.es: Donata M. de 53 años  hace 13 años emprendió el negocio de venta de frescos/gaseosas, con mucho esfuerzo logro tener un lugar de venta en la Ceja de la Ciudad de El Alto,  donde vende  cuatro días a la semana desde las 9:30 hasta la 16:00, ella tiene 7 hijos 6 de los cuales son independientes y solamente la menor está  a cargo de ella. A Donata le gusta vender y es la única fuente de ingreso por lo que ahora necesita el préstamo para comprar la kisa (durazno seco) insumo con el cual prepara los frescos, quiere comprar un kintal. A Donata le agrada la capacitación que se imparte en Pro Mujer porque es una oportunidad para aprender, también la atención que brindan en Salud. Sus compañeras al igual que Donata tienen actividades económicas diversas como la venta de carne de cordero, limpieza de ropa, venta de accesorios de belleza, transporte, venta de reloj y venta de comida. Todas necesitan el préstamo para incrementar capital de trabajo a sus negocios.
texts.en:
Donata M., 53, started selling soft-drinks 13 years ago. Through much effort she managed to secure a spot to sell in La Ceja (main commercial thoroughfare) in the city of El Alto where she works four days a week from 9:30-16:00 hours. She has 7 children 6 of which are independent; she only has one minor left at home who is dependent on her. Donata loves selling and this is her only source of income. She needs financing to buy kisa (dehydrated peach), an ingredient used to prepare juices; she wants to buy a quintal (a weight measure equal to 46 kilos.) Donata likes the training sessions that Pro Mujer imparts because they are an opportunity to learn; she also appreciates the health services they offer. Her fellow members, like Donata, have different economic activities like the sale of lamb meat, laundry sevices, sale of beauty accessories, transportation, watch sales, and prepared meal sales. They all need financing to increase their working capital.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital increase.

loans.name: Rahim

texts.en:
T. Rahim is a hard-working man who has helped strengthen the family business over many years in an effort to give his children the best. With experience gained over five years in the purchase and sales of sheep, he has been able to bring stability to his family. Rahimdjon has a friendly family that always tries to help one another. Now Rahim has decided to set off on his own by buying some animals that he will raise for a short period of time. For this reason he is requesting $1100. Rahimdjon is counting on your help and thanks you very much for your love of the underprivileged.  
  
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase sheep to raise and sell.

loans.name: Lando

texts.en:
Like many enterprising women in Africa, Ms. Lando F. doesn't just sell one thing. If she can buy something low and sell it for a bit higher, she will take it on. Currently, she sells oranges at the main market in Bambey. She began her trade in 2000, when a younger brother lent her money to buy her first stock. She enjoys the daily interactions with clients and other vendors at the market, and of course the profits she can make. She is married and the mother of six children.

UIMCEC opened a branch in the area in July of this year to better serve rural clients. With her loan of 150,000 FCFA, Ms. F. would like to purchase incense, perfumes, and thioub (a kind of traditional dress) to sell to other women in the community. She hopes the credit will increase her income enough to support her family and to help send her son to a private high school.

loans.use: To buy perfume and clothing for sale

loans.name: Paula Imelda

texts.es:
Paula es socia del Banco Comunal Emprendedora.
Paula es conviviente, tiene 48 años y 2 hijos, Paula junto a sus hijas se dedican a tejer prendas de acuerdo a los pedidos que tenga de sus cliente, como colchas, chompas, ropones. Además Paula vende ropas interiores a pedidos.
Paula necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de lana y como parte de pago de una maquina de tejer.
Los sueños de Paula son tener una empresa de tejidos e implementar un negocio para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Paula is a partner of "Banco Comunal Emprendedora. Paula lives with her significant other, is 48 years old, and has 2 children. Together with her daughters she knits garments according to orders from her customers such as blankets, sweaters and baptism robes and she sells lingerie by orders.

Paula needs a loan of 3000 soles to be invested in buying wool and pay off a knitting machine. Paula's dreams are to own an enterprise of knitted garments and set up a business for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wool and pay off a knitting machine.

loans.name: Marisol

texts.en:
Marisol P. is the 24-year-old mother of two kids. Her husband, Alvin Pascual, is a bamboo set maker. When she got married, she started a bamboo set making business. Their income is not enough to support the needs of their growing kids. Marisol joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.) in 2009 to get capital to start a secondary fishing business. Now, she applied for a second loan to buy fishing materials like fishnet, bamboo and other materials for her business. 

Marisol dreams of expanding her fish cage in the future to raise more fish. She also wants to save money from her bamboo set business to meet their daily needs. She hopes that someday, through her loans from ASHI in partnership with Kiva, she will be able to discover skills to engage in a more productive business. She dreams to get out of the ties of poverty. That is one challenge in their lives.

loans.use: To buy fishing materials like fishnet, bamboo and other supplies for her business

loans.name: Emmily

texts.en:
Emmily M., a 31-year-old mother of three children, is married to Daniel Rau. Emmily is a paraffin vendor at Mikoroshoni in Mombasa. Her clients are predominantly the area residents who are also her neighbors. She has been operating the business for one year and it has been doing well.

Emmily was introduced to KADET by a friend and is now accessing her first loan. She plans to purchase paraffin stock wholesale from Mombasa and later resell to the area households of Mikoroshoni.

Emmily operates in a semi-permanent store and hopes to expand and open up a permanent store to sell the paraffin.

loans.use: To purchase paraffin stock from Mombasa town.

loans.name: Aquelina

texts.es:
Aquelina es socia del Banco Comunal Kuskanchik que significa Todos Juntos en quechua.
Aquelina es casada, tiene 35 años y 3 hijos, Aquelina tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, verduras, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Aquelina necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de azúcar, arroz y fideo.
Los sueños de Aquelina son tener una ferretería y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Aquelina is a member of the communal bank "Kuskanchik" which means "All Together" in Quechua. Aquelina is married, 35 years old, and has three children. Aquelina has a store in her house where she sells vegetables and general groceries. She works every day. Aquelina needs a loan of 600 soles to invest in the purchase of sugar, rice, and pasta. She would love to have a hardware store one day and provide her children with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, and pasta.

loans.name: Joel De Jesus

texts.es: El Sr. Joel De Jesús Hernández M.. Se desempeña como botone en un hotel de playas tiene mas de cinco años en esta actividad conduce vehículos para transportar cliente  hacia y desde las habitaciones y otros lugares que ofrece el hotel. Este crédito lo solicito para comprar materiales de construcción para mejora en su vivienda. Es padre de 3 hijos dos en etapa escolar. Y dice que estos créditos le han beneficiado porque de otra forma es difícil hacer cambios en nuestros hogares.
texts.en:
This is Sr. Joel De Jesús Hernández M.. He has worked as a bellhop at a beach hotel for more than five years. Joel also drives the transport vehicles to take the customers to their rooms and other places around the hotel.

This loan will be used to buy construction materials to improve his home. He is the father of three children, two of whom are in school. Joel says that these loans have been beneficial because it would be difficult for him to secure another resource that would allow him to make changes to his home.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to make home improvements

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchases more chicks

loans.name: Edwar

texts.es: Edwar tiene 24 años, vive con su pequeña hija y su esposa en una casa alquilada, ubicada al sur de Lima. Desde hace 2 años se dedica a la preparación de comidas, que junto a su esposa trabajan juntos en un local alquilado cerca de su casa. En todo este tiempo han logrado captar clientes, quienes acuden cada día a partir de las 11.00AM hasta las 3.00PM de la tarde, y durante los fines de semana prepara bandejas especiales como pachamanca (carne y papas cocidas a base de piedras calientes), que es un plato típico del Perú. Sin embargo le es pesado el trabajo de formar el horno de piedras para poder cocinar la pachamanca. Pero él sabe que este trabajo le trae mucho beneficio y utilidades. Este es su primer crédito con MFP, y promete ser puntual con el pago de sus cuotas, ya que sabe que este aporte le será muy útil para su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, lo invertirá en la compra de mesas y sillas, y de ese modo brindar una buena atención  a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Edwar is 24 years old; he lives with his young daughter and his wife in a rented house located south of Lima. For 2 years now, he has been preparing and selling food; he works together with his wife in a rented establishment near their house. During this time, they have managed to capture many customers that visit them daily from 11:00 am until 3:00 pm; during the weekends, they prepare special trays such as Pachamanca (meat and potatoes cooked with hot stones) which is a traditional dish from Peru. Nevertheless, it is heavy work for them to setup the stone oven to cook the Pachamanca. However, he knows this work brings him much benefits and profits. This is his first loan with MFP, and he promises to make his payments on time since he knows this loan will be very useful for his business. With the loan he is requesting, he will invest it in buying tables and chairs to offer better service to his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Carlos Morales, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tables and chairs to offer better service to his customers

loans.name: Antonio's Group

texts.en: Antonio D. is from Barangay San Nicolas, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 56 years old and is the group leader of this five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Antonio is single. He owns and operates a business providing manicure and pedicure services in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Antonio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Antonio is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be his third from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Leoncio

texts.es:
Leoncio es un padre de familia de años de edad que vive junto a su esposa y a dos hijos en el sector Licapa del distrito de Paiján de la provincia de Ascope, en la región La Libertad, ubicado a dos horas y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica desde hace mas de dos años a brindar servicio de transporte en una mototaxi (motocicleta que tiene anexada una cabina para ofrecer servicio de transporte de carga y pasajeros) el cuenta con dos vehículos de los cuales maneja uno y el otro lo alquila a un chofer de la zona. En el distrito de Paiján este medio de transporte es muy usado debido a que es barato. Adicionalmente el posee ganado vacuno del cual comercializa la leche que producen a un acopiador. Los ingresos que le proveen estas actividades los utiliza en el sostenimiento de su familia.

Debido al constante uso, la mototaxi que suele manejar ha empezado a sufrir algunas fallas técnicas que requieren de urgente solución para garantizar su correcto funcionamiento, por este motivo el ha solicitado a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la reparación y mantenimiento de su vehículo.

Leoncio es una persona trabajadora y responsable, su mayor anhelo es seguir desarrollandose como ganadero y llegar a tener su propio establo, el ya ha trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado puntualidad y responsabilidad al momento de asumir sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Leoncio is an older parent and lives with his wife and two children in the Licapa sector in the district of Paiján, Ascope province, in the region of La Libertad, located two and a half hours from the city of Chiclayo, the capital of the Lambayeque region. For more than two years he has provided a mototaxi transportation service (a motorcycle that has a cab attached to provide transport service for cargo or passengers). He has two vehicles, one of which he drives and the other he rents to a local driver. In the district of Paiján this mode of transport is very popular because it is cheap. Additionally, Leoncio owns cattle and he sells the milk that they produce to a distributor. The income that these activities provide Leoncio uses to sustain his family. Under constant use, the mototaxi that he usually drives has begun to suffer a few technical failures that require an urgent solution to guarantee that it will function correctly. This motive has led him to seek a loan of 500 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa that he plans to invest in the repair and maintenance of his vehicle. Leoncio is a hardworking and responsible person, his greatest desire is to continue developing dhis herd of cattle and to eventually have his own barn. He has previously worked with Edpyme Alternativa and has demonstrated punctuality and responsibility in fulfilling his repayments.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly McKinnon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the costs of repairing and maintaining his mototaxi

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy trousers, shirts and bags to sell

loans.name: Denia

texts.en:
Denia D. is a single woman who lives in Prk. Papaya, Tabao Rizal, San Enrique, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: food vending and a general store. 

Denia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five cycle loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Denia has incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow.  Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 3,000. 

This time, for her 6th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000 to buy ingredients for food vending so that she could continue to save up for the future and to expand the business. Denia D. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

-------------------------------------------
About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Scholastica

texts.en:
Scholastica M. is a 40-year-old single lady with four children.  She operates Friends Shop in her local community.  Since she is the breadwinner in her family, she works hard to educate her children.  Therefore, she also does tailoring and sells charcoal for more income.  

She is an active member of Bright Angels group in Faulu Kenya because she attends the group meetings regularly and pays her weekly dues well. She has been guaranteed a loan of 15,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) by the group members.  She will use this loan to add stock of charcoal. She hopes to expand her retail shop into a wholesale shop for more income.

loans.use: buying charcoal for resale

loans.name: Doris

texts.es:
Doris nació y vive en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo.  La mayoría de pobladores que viven en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo se dedican al turismo y otros pobladores que viven alrededor se dedican a la agricultura y ganadería. Doris  hace 15 años atrás abrió un pequeño hospedaje “La Casa de Doris”, en su domicilio, donde hospeda a turistas nacionales y extranjeros. Ella y su esposo Américo tienen un hijo. Doris en su hospedaje tiene cuartos matrimoniales, simple y dobles, donde los precios oscilan entre 20 soles o 50 soles dependiendo el cuarto. Le pueden encontrar en su hospedaje, que está equipado de computadoras personales  para acceder a internet, cocina, sala de espera, baños privados, etc. todos los días de la semana, las 24 horas del día.  Doris desprende una imagen de amabilidad y alegría. Un flujo regular de turistas se hospeda durante los meses de mayo, junio, julio y agosto. 

Con  su próximo préstamo, Doris espera recibir $200 USD. Por el momento, su hospedaje esta modestamente equipado con las necesidades más básicas. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo para ampliar el hospedaje y desea comprar ventanas y puertas para la parte que están construyendo.
texts.en:
Doris was born in the city of Ollantaytambo and still lives there. Most of the people of Ollantaytambo work in the field of tourism, while others who live outside the city work in farming and ranching. Fifteen years ago, Doris opened a small inn, “La Casa de Doris” ["Doris's House"] in her home, where she hosts foreign and domestic tourists. She and her husband Américo have one child. In her inn, Doris has single, double and family rooms, with prices ranging from 20 to 50 soles depending on the room. Every day of the week, 24 hours a day, she can be found in her inn, which is equipped with personal computers for Internet access, a kitchen, a waiting room, private bathrooms, etc. Doris projects an image of friendliness and cheerfulness. A steady flow of tourists stays at the inn during the months of May, June, July and August. With her next loan, Doris hopes to receive $200 in US dollars. For the moment, her inn is modestly equipped with the most basic needs. She would like to use the funds to help expand her inn, buying windows and doors for the new part that is under construction.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying windows and doors

loans.name: Juana Francisca

texts.es: Juana Francisca tiene 60 años, Ella se dedica a la venta de ropa y granos básicos. Por lo que siempre está buscando la forma de mejorar sus ingresos es su mayor fuente de ingreso para su familia, hace más de 11 años que se dedica a este negocio, siempre se ha preocupado por mejorar sus ingresos, por lo que tiene una gran variedad de clientes mantener estos negocios no ha sido fácil, pues la situación económica que atraviesa el país. Este crédito es para la compra de materia prima como pantalones, camisas, faldas y vestidos también arroz, aceite entre otras cosas.
texts.en:
Juana Francisca is 60 and she works selling clothing and basic grains. She began this business more than 11 years ago because she is always looking for a better way to increase her income for her family. She is always worried about getting more earnings and to have many types of customers in this business hasn't been easy. The economic situation has had an impact across the country. This loan will be used to buy merchandise such as pants, shirts, skirts, and dresses as well as rice, oil and more.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: ropa

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi G. is married and has five dependents. She has been through senior high school.

Esi sells bananas and other fruit at Elmina and uses her income to support her husband in enhancing the well-being of her family.

Esi will use the loan to purchase more fruit to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans on reinvesting in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit to sell

loans.name: Perveen

texts.en: Perveen is a resident of Kasur, a small city located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and famous for its leather industry. She operates an embroidery business in her home to supplement the income of her family. She is excellent in her art and, due to the quality of her work, she receives regular orders from her customers. By making a good income from this business, she has become an additional earning hand of her family. She is the mother of a son and four daughters. Her son is a daily wage laborer and her eldest daughter helps Perveen in her embroidery business. The remaining three daughters stay at home and manage the household chores. Her husband works in Pakistan railways on a monthly wage. Her brother-in-law also lives with her. He sells fruits from his cart and contributes to the family financially. Perveen has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her brother-in-law. With the loan, he will buy seasonal fruits for his fruit-selling business. Perveen is hopeful that, by making this investment, her brother-in-law will improve his business and increase his income. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years she always attended the meetings and paid installments on time.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits for fruit-selling business

loans.name: Maria Calixta

texts.es: María Calixta tiene 53 años, pues esta no es la primera vez que realiza un financiamiento para su negocio. Ella es una mujer que siempre ha luchado por mantener a su familia además de esto ha pasado grandes desafíos como es la competencia pero ella ofrece buena calidad de productos y además sus clientes están acostumbrados al buen servicio que ofrece. Se dedica a la venta de tortillas, frijoles y leña.  Por lo que solicita este crédito para la compra de materia prima necesaria para su negocio ya que así obtendrá nuevos clientes.
texts.en:
María Calixta is 53 years old. This is not the first time that she has had a loan for her business.

She is a woman who has always fought to support her family. In addition, she has faced great challenges, such as competition, but she offers good quality products, and her customers are accustomed to the good service she provides.

She is engaged in the sale of tortillas, beans, and firewood. She is applying for this loan in order to purchase raw materials for her business since this will allow her to obtain new customers.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Nelva Elizabeth

texts.es:
En la ciudadela Las Orquídeas  de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal los Ceibos, esta es una zona urbana marginal donde las personas se dedican a diversas actividades.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Nelva. Tiene 49 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual ha procreado cinco hijos dos de ellos ya mayores de edad. Tres de sus hijas estudian una en universidad y dos en el colegio el mayor ya es independiente. Su marido se dedica al comercio.

Tiene una imprenta y papelería en el centro de la ciudad donde arrienda un local, trabaja de lunes a sábado desde las 8am hasta las 18h00, trabaja con la ayuda de dos personas a la cuales les paga un sueldo mensual, nos cuenta que en las temporadas de inicio de clases tiene que contratar personal, sus productos los recibe en su local, compra en diversos lugares en cuanto a sus productos se refiere.

Este crédito es para compra papeles para la copiadora, libros y cuadernos de distintos tipos. Es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal  y le gusta por las facilidades de pago.

Sus sueños son tener un local propio para ahorrar el pago del arriendo y comprarse un carro.
texts.en:
The communal bank Los Ceibos meets every two weeks in the residential area of Las Orquideas in the city of Portoviejo.  This is a poorer urban area where people do different types of work.

Mrs. Nelva, 49, lives here.  She is in a common-law marriage and she has 5 children, two that are adults.  Three are of her daughters are studying in a university, two are in high school and the oldest is now on his own.  Her husband is in business.

She has a printing and stationery shop in the center of the city where she rents a shop.  She works Mondays to Saturdays from 8 am to 6 pm with the help of two employees who are paid monthly.  She tells us that at the beginning of classes she has to hire help and she buys the merchandise in different locations and she has the products delivered.

This loan will be used to buy paper for the copier, books and assorted kinds of notebooks.  She is a founding member of the communal bank and she likes it for the ease of payments.

Her dreams are to have her own store to save the rent money and to buy herself a car.

loans.use: To buy papers, books and notebooks

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel M. N. is 34 years old, married, and has two children. He sells second-hand shoes in the Kenol open air market in Muranga.  He has been in the business for 10 years and earns a profit of about 3,000  KES per month.

He is applying for his third loan from KADET having repaid the other loans.  He will use the loan to  expand his business by adding more stock of  shoes to sell during the festive season.  He hopes to buy land and build his residential home and expand his business.

loans.use: To add more stock of shoes to sell

loans.name: Loida

texts.es: Loida, de 30 años, es una valerosa madre soltera, que junto a sus 5 hijos: Jelsy, de 13, Nicol, de 12 y Talía, de 8 años de edad, vive en unión familiar en su casa propia, ubicada en la comunidad de Sanchirio (selva central peruana). Aunque se siente sola en la lucha por educar a sus hijos, Loida no se rinde, ya que según afirma, todos los días reza a Dios para que le de fuerzas, y así pueda salir adelante. Hace 3 años que se dedica a la agricultura, donde tienen más de 3 hectáreas de terrenos agrícolas, donde siembra café y plátano. Sus cosechas, gracias a Dios, los venden a muy buen precio. Por ello hace un par de años acondicionó una pequeña tienda de abarrotes en su casa, donde todos los días sus pobladores le compran productos de primera necesidad, pero su mayor prioridad es tener capital para invertir en la agricultura. Es el segundo crédito con MFP, ya tiene aproximadamente 2 años trabajando con su banco comunal, donde asegura son personas, comprometidas con el trabajo. Con el crédito que reciba, comprará 5 sacos de abono orgánico, como también en la compra de productos para surtir su tienda de comestibles.
texts.en: Loida, 30 years old, is a courageous single mother of 3 children: Jelsy (13), Nicol (12) and Talía (8); she has a live-in partner and lives in her own house which is located in the community of Sanchirio (Peruvian central jungle). Although she feels alone in the fight to educate her children, Loida does not give up according to her own statements that she prays to God every day to grant her the strength so she can get ahead in life. She has been in the agriculture business for 3 years; she has 3 hectares (unit of measure equivalent to 10,000 square meters or 2.5 acres) of land where she grows coffee and bananas. Her crops, thanks to God, sell at good prices. Consequently, she setup a grocery store in her house where the nearby inhabitants buy basic necessity products every day, but her main priority is to have capital to invest in agriculture. This is the second loan with MFP; she has been working approximately 2 years with her community bank, where she believes the people are committed to their work. With the loan she will receive, she will buy 5 sacks of organic fertilizer as well as products to stock up her grocery store.

loans.use: Buy sacks of fertilizer and products to stock up her store

loans.name: Elpedio

texts.en:
Elpedio C. is from the town of Trinidad. He is 47 years old, married and has 5 children. His eldest child is 20 years old and the youngest is 10. Elpedio owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Elpedio has been planting and harvesting vegetables for almost 10 years and earns approximately PHP 3,000 per month.

Elpedio joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Elpedio is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies.
